guide.abstract: The Gentoo Documentation Project is an official Gentoo Linux project devoted to the complete and concise documentation of Gentoo Linux.

chapter.title: What is the Gentoo Documentation Project?

section.title: What we do, and who we are

body.p: The Gentoo Documentation Project (GDP) is an official sub-project of the Gentoo Linux project responsible for the creation and maintenance of all official Gentoo Linux documentation. The GDP is not a closed team of any sorts, but instead an open community commited to critiqing, and possibly integrating, viable user documentation.

The purpose of the Gentoo Documentation Project is to create complete and concise Gentoo centric documentation. Creation of Gentoo documentation can happen in many fashions. With the consent and assistance of the original author, documentation can be created from the Gentoo Forums, the GDP wiki, (under development) or documentation from the gentoo-doc mailing list.

The GDP team upholds a strict policy against plagarism. We will not use documentation that cannot be verified to an original author, as well as documentation that does not have specific consent from the original author.
Official Gentoo Linux documentation can be found on the gentoo.org website, indexed at the documentation index.
Offical GDP documentation, such as developer HOWTOs and translator HOWTOs, can be found at the GDP documentation index.
Documentation that is in development, can be found at the GDP wiki, which is still under development itself.
If you are having a problem accessing either of the aforementioned documentation, please post a bug on the Gentoo Bugtraqing system.

The current active subprojects in the Gentoo Documentation Project are:
Project: Description:
Gentoo Core documentation Core documentation, such as the arch specific installation guides, and the Desktop Guide, are maintained in this project. Project members will work closely with many other teams in the Gentoo Linux hierarchy to make absolutely positive that our most important documentation is one-hundred percent correct and up to date.
User Application documentation The core of the GDP team, most of the work in this subproject relates to the maintenance and incorportation of application centric documentation.
System documentation The Portage documentation, rc-scripts guide, and other Gentoo specific documentation is covered under this subproject. The goal of this subproject is to completely document what makes Gentoo, Gentoo.
International documentation As Gentoo continues to grow, international documentation will be key to communicating with our diverse user base. The translators will make sure that all Gentoo documentation is translated in a timely fashion.

The current planned subprojects in the Gentoo Documentation Project are:
Project: Description:
Documentation submission engine Since most documentation is submitted by Gentoo users, there needs to be an easier way for the GDP team to track and edit new user documentation. This subproject will focus on the creation of an offical submission system and offical submission policy.
Printable documentation GDP documentation needs to be printer compatible. This subproject will completely oversee the planning and implementation of making GDP documentation printer friendly.
Man page creation There are many packages in the Portage tree that need man pages.
Translations There is a need for full time translators in all languages.
Each GDP developer is listed here, along with their respective responsibilities.

To participate in the Gentoo Documentation Project first join the mailing list at gentoo-doc@gentoo.org. Then ask if there are plans to support something that you are interested in, propose a new subproject that you are interested in, or choose one of the planned subprojects to work on. You may talk to the developers and users in the IRC channel #gentoo-doc on irc.freenode.net for more information or just to chat about the project or any subprojects. If you don't have the ability to actively help by contributing work we will always need editors to maintain the quality and accuracy of the overall product. All development, editing, and productive comments and feedback will be greatly appreciated.
